B002QEXBGS|5.0|JACQUES OFFENBACH'S ORPH&Eacute;E AUX ENFERS (ORPHEUS IN THE UNDERWORLD)<br />a production by the Op&eacute;ra National de Lyon, ArtHaus Music, 2009.<br /><br />I was not familiar with this work when I bought it. I only ordered it because Natalie Dessay is in it. The box calls it an Opera Buffa. Were Offenbach German, for a second or so I thought it might have been called a singspiel. [The word in German means 'sing-play'. But believe me it bears little relationship to the singspiel I know best, The Marriage of Figaro, so I abandoned that notion post-haste. Singspiels are in every way an opera except in an opera the connections between arias and other melodic parts are declaimed as recitatives, usually accompanied by harpsichord,  cello, or orchestra, whereas in a singspiel they are spoken. A recitative is vaguely similar to a chant. Very vaguely.]The liner notes claim Orphe'''e was the first operetta when it premiered in 1858. Whatever the appropriate category, I call it outrageous, x-rated fun, full of comedy, farce, and slapstick.<br /><br />The story is a takeoff on the myth of Orpheus in the Underworld, where he goes to retrieve his wife, Eurydice. I shall not betray the plot and spoil your fun, but here are some of the incidentals that make it a sketch: The cast all have Dr. Spock ears. The Corps de Ballet is composed of men and women, both in traditional ballet dress. Two of the chorus are visibly pregnant. The Greek dramatic `Chorus' is replaced by `Public Opinion', a woman who reminds me of a prude in my childhood church. Jupiter (called `Jupie' by his relatives, gods and demi-gods on Olympus) is at war with Pluto (his brother and the god of the underworld). Juno, Jupiter's wife, runs around in an old fashioned corset (or something like that; I am not too up on women's underclothes of times before the present) and turns out to be bald. The Olympiad gods, demi-gods, and relatives of Jubie's revolt against the boredom of heaven and of having his providing them only with nectar and ambrosia, instead of the Lyon sausage brought up to Olympus by Pluto from Hades, in snowshoes, using ski poles. Venus and Cupid return in the early morning to Olympus after separate one night stands on earth. There is a drunken orgy in this afterword. And Eurydice and a giant fly make love all the while singing `Zz. Zz. Zz.\\"<br /><br />The music ranges from the intricate, complicated, and adroit to the familiar (Can-Can). All of the voices are superb, with Dessay at her usual brilliant best as coloratura and actress (in this case, comedienne).<br /><br />This production of the Ope'ra National de Lyon was recorded live in 1997. Dessay, singing with it, relative to the Op'era de Paris reminds me of Beverly Sills at the New York City Opera relative to the Metropolitan Opera. I respectfully suggest that you watch it with a bunch of your musically aware buds with lots of wine flowing. You will understand why I say this by the end of the show.<br /><br />Dessay is an operatic genius, if one is permitted to speak this way. Most singers, when they play a role, make it plain they are first and foremost singers, not actors. Even the best of them, in which the acting is superb, never let you forget their primary occupation. Not Natalie Dessay. When she acts I forget she is a coloratura par excellence. I forget even that she is acting. She is her role, whether in DVD's as Olympia in The Tales of Hoffmann (the funniest characterization I ever saw in an opera) or as Mad Ophelia in Hamlet (where the audience with incessant clapping will not, absolutely will not let her arise from the floor at the conclusion of the scene). But the voice is always there. No matter how her body is contorted by the Director or she is moving about to express the role, it is ever the same--beyond belief., instead of the Lyon sausage brought up to Olympus by Pluto from Hades, in snowshoes, using ski poles. Venus and Cupid return in the early morning to Olympus after separate one night stands on earth. There is a drunken orgy in this afterword. And Eurydice and a giant fly make love all the while singing `Zz. Zz. Zz.\\"    The music ranges from the intricate, complicated, and adroit to the familiar (Can-Can). All of the voices are superb, with Dessay at her usual brilliant best as coloratura and actress (in this case, comedienne).    This production of the Opera National de Lyon was recorded live in 1997. Dessay, singing with it, relative to the Opera de Paris reminds me of Beverly Sills at the New York City Opera relative to the Metropolitan Opera. I respectfully suggest that you watch it with a bunch of your musically aware buds with lots of wine flowing. You will understand why I say this by the end of the show.    Dessay is an operatic genius, if one is permitted to speak this way. Most singers, when they play a role, make it plain they are first and foremost singers, not actors. Even the best of them, in which the acting is superb, never let you forget their primary occupation. Not Natalie Dessay. When she acts I forget she is a coloratura par excellence. I forget even that she is acting. She is her role, whether in DVD's as Olympia in The Tales of Hoffmann (the funniest characterization I ever saw in an opera) or as Mad Ophelia in Hamlet (where the audience with incessant clapping will not, absolutely will not let her arise from the floor at the conclusion of the scene). B000053GTK|5.0|\\"Unique\\" is definitely the word of the day when it concerns Gentle Giant.   In fact, you know what?  Don't ever say \\"unique\\" again unless you follow it up with the words \\"Gentle Giant\\".  What makes this band so incredible?  Dig this, young grasshopper-    One second you're hearing a beautiful folk rock guitar solo that quite possibly might make you think about old countryside forgotten castles, the next minute you're hearing gently-implemented xylophone fairies dancing in a highly unusual fashion, and *then* before you're able to grasp what finally hit you, some exceptionally weird chant-like Sunday church vocal melody slaps you against the face and makes you a believer for life.      All this stuff happens in just ONE song, and it happens *all* the time!  Now tell me, what other band would have the courage to do all THAT?    Where did this band come from?  What kind of music did the band members listen to while growing up?  Did their parents approve of their (I assume) whacky sense of humor?   Maybe they weren't even normal kids?  Maybe the teacher would smack their wrists with a ruler every time they spoke out of term.  Maybe the band members didn't have any parents and just appeared as aliens.  Hey, you never know. :)    \\"The Runaway\\" opens this completely unique blend of musical creativity on a REALLY high note.  The vocals chug along to the rhythm and the guitar playing except... the vocals don't actually chug along to it.  Yes, it's true!  It's an illusion!  Believe me, I tell you no lie!  The vocals don't chug along to *anything*.   It's tricky business!  Things just appear whenever the band *feels* like having them appear.  Why?  Because no one else would have done such a thing back then.  You had to be different back in the 70's to make it big (or create orchestrated, sappy ballads).    It always WORKS though.  Whatever they try works.  I have no earthly idea how the band members were able to keep repeating the same formula for so many albums and for so many years, and never miss a beat the whole time they were doing it!  True talent of the highest caliber.    That's what makes Gentle Giant so extraordinary- listen closely to the way they lay down their vocals.  Ain't ever two instruments matching up together in a normal, predictable way.  Ain't ever, I tell ya!  If they are, it's extremely hard to notice it.    One thing this band most certainly isn't is boring.  If you think Gentle Giant is boring, you deserve to live in a cardboard box with rats, spiders and bums.  Would be crazy to believe such a stinky thing.    \\"An Inmates Lullaby\\" is a baby shower display of peaceful xylophone taps and even *more* peaceful (and melodically intricate!) vocals.  Actually, this is more like baby delivery room music.  You know, that room in the hospital where all the newborn babies sleep until the mother makes her grand entrance into the room.  That room with a huge window outside of it as you watch over all the sleeping babies.  I hope I never have to go inside that room.  The thought of potentially waking up over 50 sleeping babies would be enough to make ME cry the loudest.  :)    This song is perfect for such a delightful occasion!  Anyway, I love when the vocals rush along at the end of specific lines so the xylophone has a chance to take its turn into the world of dazzling Willy Wonka creations.  It's weird how the band makes it work.  Don't know what I'm talking about?  Doesn't matter 'cuz everyone hears something different anyway!  And with that in mind, I can say no wrong, bubs!    Quite possibly the strangest way to write music my ears ever did hear, but Gentle Giant does the *same exact tricky thing* quite often, so I'm totally used to their style by now.  *You* probably won't be used to it however, if In a Glass House happens to be your very first Gentle Giant experience.  They say experience Hendrix.  No no, experience THIS band.      \\"Way of Life\\" is my favorite song from the album.  I just love the way the vocals aredisplayed here.  Again, the vocals appear to follow along to the rhythm section and the guitar riff, but then suddenly, in a moment of \\"What the HECK just happened?\\" the guitar either overrides the vocals and cancels them out so you can't actually hear the vocals anymore, or the lead singer stops singing the line inexplicitly because even HE can't help but fall in love with the guitar playing, so he shuts his crazy lips and opens his ears.  It's hard to explain which one is actually taking place here!      BUT THAT'S NOT ALL!  The second half of the song features a drop-dead gorgeous blonde... I mean tear-shedding moment of balladry that's so touching and moving that even the devil himself has to blow out his flames and put down his pitchfork.     GOSH what a head scratcher this stuff can be!  You gotta be somewhat crazy to listen to the classic period of Gentle Giant, me thinks.    \\"Experience\\" is flat out freakin' awesome.  I actually like this song almost as much as \\"Way of Life\\".  It's really constructed in a highly unusual way.  \\"Yeah, no duh!  *Everything* Gentle Giant does is constructed in a highly unusual way you rocket scientist!\\" you're probably saying to yourself.  Maybe you're even saying it out loud.  It's perfectly normal to talk to yourself as long as you don't answer your own questions.  That's what I was told.  :)    Anyway, the part at the end when the song completely rocks out in a way that would surely make Huey Lewis proud is definitely quite groovy and might even encourage you to overcome your shyness and shake those sexy buns to the sophisticated tempo changes taking place.  Here's something to think about- if you could dance to this music, you'd be the clear winner on the next season of the smash hit reality show Dancing With the Stars.  I guarantee it.     I probably should have mentioned \\"Experience\\" after that \\"experience Hendrix\\" comment to make my review seem more organized, but oh well.  I'm not going to change anything for the sake of organization.  Besides, you're probably not aware of it, but I have obsessive compulsive disorder, so it's about time I fight my inner battles!  It ends now!    The title song is really cool.  Again, the heavy rocking out section at the end is super melodic and super dang cool, dudes.  I need to stop getting this song confused with \\"The Runaway\\" though. It's a common mistake so you must forgive me.     Oh, did I forget to mention \\"A Reunion?\\".  No, I won't be attending my 10-year high school reunion (Why bother?  I had no friends and all the hot girls are taken!) but that doesn't mean this can't be an exquisite 2-minute piece of fine cuisine music.  My manners immediately become more appropriate just by listening to it.  It's melodic too.  I love it.  I love how the song really DOES capture the feeling of wanting to go back and experience a specific period in time.  Of course, again, it does make you think about fancy dinner parties as well.  It's caught between two very different worlds involving very different people.     I love Gentle Giant.  Their music is actually very easy to get into despite their highly sophisticated way of putting music together.  Everything they did just screams with immediately accessible and repetitive melodies (and I mean that as a compliment because they repeat the GOOD stuff).  Later ya'll.
B002QN7PU2|3.0|Seriously, the close ups of cars, Apple, Red Bull and Sugar in the Raw of all things ? I will never buy those products , it has the opposite effect on me. 0743298039|1.0|Robert Graves once said: \\"A thing that's remarkable about Shakespeare is that he is really very good, in spite of all the people who say he is very good.\\" This quote carries a lot of truth, and it is a remarkable thing about Shakespeare, because if you judge books by their Amazon reviews, nothing that's generally considered very good ever turns out to be. This applies to the The Thirteenth Tale. Despite all the people who said it was great, it turned out to be just the opposite. In fact, it was utter tripe. Though I fully expect to be torn apart because of my dissenting view on a book many seem to adore, I must say I found it to be completely awful.<br /><br />The story centers around Margaret, a completely boring character of no or little account, who really likes to read. She loves Jane Eyre (this trend of title-dropping in novels is starting to annoy me, especially since it always seems that it's a Bronte or an Austen title that gets dropped randomly into the mix just to show that the characters can read classics). She was born a conjoined twin and was the only one of them to survive birth. Her dead twin \\"haunts\\" her. The other main character is Vida Winter, a famous author who has never told the truth about her life but wants to tell it now to Margaret, who is an amateur biographer. The story of Vida's life takes up the main plot of the book, and it is a overly-dramatic, badly written, pseudo-Gothic tale of one-dimensional maniacs. I don't have a problem reading about people who are a little, or even very, insane. After all, I love Philippa Gregory's Wideacre. But when every single character is either messed-up, repulsive, moronic, or boring, (or, actually, all four of these things at once) it makes for painful reading.<br /><br />[SPOILERS AHEAD] Vida and Margaret are both uninteresting and they do not play a great part in the story really. The other characters, however, are just irritating. From Isabelle and Charlie (the siblings who have a freaky relationship that's implied to be incestuous) to Adeline and Emmeline (Isabelle and Charlie's twins who are mentally unstable-- Adeline, especially, is abusive, jealous, and fond of ripping apart topiary gardens and stealing perambulators with babies inside them). There was no depth to their stories.  Nothing was revealed about their characters, their emotions. The most complex of all the characters, in fact, was Hester, the governess who is merely a background character. Besides this flat characterization and the author's obvious yet failed attempt at utilizing a Gothic shock-factor, if you will, there is the problem of the author's prose, which is cliche-ridden and embarrassing to read. Margaret often waxes lyrical on the subject of her dead twin, and Vida Winter, who is supposed to be a genius of tremendous proportions, reveals parts of her writing that are mediocre at best. Finally, the last few chapters are handled so clumsily that it seems as though the author wrote it all in about a week and never revised. The big plot twist basically undermines everything in the rest of the story and is basically the disappointing and weak \\"ta-da\\" moment at the end of an unimpressive magic trick. And more to the point, it positively bored me. [END SPOILERS]<br /><br />This novel is an insult to the reader's intelligence. It tries to make itself sound profound and smart but it fails miserably and instead sounds inane. It was largely filled with pop psych on twins, which sounded as if it had been taken out of a book written by a New Age Freud wanna-be. It was completely ridiculous. None of the characters were likable or realistic or, worst of all, engaging. And the writing was messy. I see no reason why I should recommend it at all, so I would say, if there's absolutely nothing else to read except a copy of The Thirteenth Tale, find a cereal box and read the back of that instead.to be incestuous) to Adeline and Emmeline (Isabelle and Charlie's twins who are mentally unstable-- Adeline, especially, is abusive, jealous, and fond of ripping apart topiary gardens and stealing perambulators with babies inside them). The most complex of all the characters, in fact, was Hester, the governess who is merely a background character. Besides this flat characterization and the author's obvious yet failed attempt at utilizing a Gothic shock-factor, if you will, there is the problem of the author's prose, which is cliche-ridden and embarrassing to read. Margaret often waxes lyrical on the subject of her dead twin, and Vida Winter, who is supposed to be a genius of tremendous proportions, reveals parts of her writing that are mediocre at best. Finally, the last few chapters are handled so clumsily that it seems as though the author wrote it all in about a week and never revised. The big plot twist basically undermines everything in the rest of the story and is basically the disappointing and weak \\"ta-da\\" moment at the end of an unimpressive magic trick. None of the characters were likable or realistic or, worst of all, engaging. And the writing was messy. I see no reason why I should recommend it at all, so I would say, if there's absolutely nothing else to read except a copy of The Thirteenth Tale, find a cereal box and read the back of that instead.

B001HN6940|3.0|The classic Alice in Wonderland story by Lewis Carroll is, in my opinion, a thin story. It was a profound statement regarding the fantastic for it's time but does not hold a candle to modern masterpieces of fantasy fiction. But it is nothing if not weird, and weirdness is what longtime fantasy director Tim Burton thrives on. What makes Alice inn Wonderland ultimately nothing special is the fact that it succumbs to the thinness of Carroll's storyline. Burton innovates the same way High School Musical 3 innovates from High School Musical 2, by taking Alice through the same steps that Carroll laid out for her as a teenager instead of a hapless little girl. There is no painting of roses in this take on Wonderland, or Underland, as Burton's creatures continously call it.             As in any Tim Burton film, we find Johnny Depp and Helena Bonham Carter doing what they do best, being strange. Mrs. Carter and Mr. Depp are both very accomplished actors outside of the Burton sphere, but under his direction they are nothing nore than glorified chadpricatures, circus sideshow acts to be ogled at and talked about by audience after audience. They are buzz generating vehicles, which make both the Mad Hatter and the Queen of Hearts very one dimensional characters, interesting but without depth.             I argue that Alice in Wonderland is attractively designed and weird enough to focus a certain degree of interest, but the plot is wandering and boring, with an ineffective, complete with a made for 3-D climax. Best to skip this one.

1615230823|5.0|This book dissects what factors create a successful person.  Gladwell admits that there must be a minimum of inate ability which exceeds the average, but he demonstrates that ability alone cannot guarantee success.  Other factors that affect success are family background, ethnicity, persistence, practice, and luck.  Being born at the right place at the right time has as much to do with success as education.  This is luck pure and simple. As a student of statistics I know that one can cite statistics to support any theory.  One just chooses particular statistics.  Gladwell's theories are interesting and thought provoking but should not be taken as the gospel. His theories dictate different solutions for educational dilemmas.  Here , however, is an example of a fallacy.  He determines that every music maestro completes 10,000 hours of practice. An ordinary musical performer will complete 6000 hours and music teachers will complete 4000 hours.  He deduces that every highly successful person has engaged in 10,000 hours of practice in his/her chosen field. Gladwell concludes that 10,000 hours of practice is the path to success. But he cannot address the issue of whether or not a more talented musician tends to practice more.  Perhaps, the more talented musician derives more pleasure out of his production and thus is induced to practice more hours.  So does the mastery come from practice or does the practice arise from the talent.  There is no way to separate these threads and Gladwell does not attempt to do so. Perhpas, they are too entwined to be separated.  If you read this book for other theories of what makes people successful but not for rules set in stone, you will be satisfied and rewarded.  Clearly, the implications his theories have for closing the gap between the poor and the rich in schools is itself worth the read.  Still without this analysis most people would agree that a longer school day, more homework, and shorter summer vacations will increase poor children's learning.  He does not address how that same formula would affect rich children's learning.  That is the fallacy.  Still this is an easy breezy read about the social phenomenon of success.

Julianne Moore, as his closest friend gets only a fraction of Firth's screen time but nearly equal billing. While she is good, she is no match for Firth. B003LXM1RS|2.0|This is an early response, but my initial reaction to this CD is that I'm pretty underwhelmed.  I love the Scissor Sisters and thought both of their other CDs were *excellent* (and unlike some, I think \\"Ta-Dah\\" is wonderful).  But \\"Night Work\\" has left me indifferent and wanting to put on something else instead.    The songs seem more like \\"homages,\\" rather than heartfelt or innate.  I hate to say it, but a lot of this comes across as derivative and without much unique personality, and very few songs stand out.  \\"Night Work\\" feels \\"small\\" and limiting, almost \\"ghetto\\" in a way--which is the opposite of either of their other CDs, both of which were \\"big\\" in their ambitions and worldview so to speak.  Maybe this will grow on me, but for now, I think I'm up for listening to something else.  (Truthfully, \\"Night Work\\" has put me in the mood for some NIN/Trent Reznor.)    UPDATE:  Having heard this a number of times now, I stand by initial reaction to it.  I do like some songs more than on first listen, but the whole thing just strikes me as a misfire.  If the \\"concept\\" behind the disc, according to something Jake Shears said, is that the music re-imagines what \\"gay\\"/club music would sound like today if AIDS did not stop it in tracks and this is an artistic response to that abyss, while I suppose this is as valid a \\"what if\\" answer as mine would be, I just don't think we would be hearing this music today even if AIDS did not exist.  Music grows and evolves over time, pop music in the 1950s grew into the Beatles and 1960s psychedelia and has since continued to go on its own trajectory, building upon what came before it.  What gay/club music of the 1970s *might* have evolved into, in my best guess, is....Scissor Sisters circa 2004.  Their debut in 2004, which was further enhanced by Ta-Dah, was a very clever and charming evolution of music that still retains its essential gay sensibility and perspective.  So to my minds, \\"Night Work\\" can be best thought of as an inoffensivebut rather uncreative \\"tribute\\" to an era that adds nothing.  Sadly, it also strikes me as a step sideways for a very creative band that still has plenty yet to say and do. They just didn't say and do it this time around.

The Girl Who Played with Fire is even better than the 1st book although both are important because they address violence towards women, prejudice, corruption, and so many other important thought provoking issues. It is also very disturbing that he did not make a will and his father and brother speak of his live-in love as his misogynist characters describe Lisbeth.  Read this book and experience an entertaining, disturbing read.  Lisbeth Sander is an unforgettable woman fictional character techno-equipped for the  21st century that many of us wish we had on our side; ditto: for Bloomkvist.  I feel like a combination of them both writing and YouTubing about corruption here in NYC.  My YouTube thoughts on movie and books.... [...].

B001GCUO5M|4.0|I go to the movies to be entertained, so I won't watch mind-polluting slasher horror movies. I watched the trailer for this movie in the theaters, and it turned me off. The movie certainly looked like a violent slasher movie, even though it was made by arguable the best director in the business Martin Scorsese. Scorsese usually has good taste. So I didn't see this till it came out on DVD.<br /><br />Set in the mid fifties, Federal Marshall Teddy Daniels (Leonardo diCaprio) and his sidekick Chuch Aule (Mark Ruffalo) go to a maximum security metal institute for the criminally insane on Shudder Island. (You've seen this place before, in the Batman movies it's usually called Arkham Asylum, a reference to the books of HP Lovecraft).  The marshals are going to investigate the disappearance of an inmate who vanished as if she \\"evaporated through the walls\\". Daniels sees sights which stir his memories, as a WWII soldier he was amongst those who liberated the Dachau Concentration Camp. On Shudder Island he finds the creepy Dr Cawley (Ben Kingley) and creepier German Dr. Nehring (Max von Sydow) and wonders if they are hiding something.  DiCaprio searchers and unravels mysteries during a hurricane on the atmospheric, gothic Shudder Island.<br /><br />I won't describe the plot and ending further, others have said far too much already. I will say the violence and tension is mostly  psycholgical, not graphic. By the fifties, there was the seemingly barbaric electroshock therapy, zapping their brains with high voltage (which I've read actually sometimes works). There was the more barbaric lobotomies, taking a knife, going between the eyeballs and the brain and slicing off the connection between the prefrontal lobe and the rest of the brain which left the violent patients passive zombies. (This happened to singer actress Francis Farmer and many others before being banned) . Then there was the new drug therapies like Thorazine. That was about it. Into this mix came Dr RD Laing who argued, with the non-violent patients, why not let these crazies walk around, act out their delusional fantasies, and talk to doctors like real people. Eventually they will logically conclude they aren't really Jesus Christ, Superman, or who ever these delusionals think they are. And they will be cured with logic and not psychiatry, drugs, knives or electric shocks.tients, chaining them to the walls or even beating them. B0038P9LTU|5.0|After getting a contractual cornholing from Joey Demaio and Magic Circle music, and being stuck in legal limbo for almost half a decade, Rhapsody are back with one of the best releases of their career and certainly the best since 2002s Power of the Dragonflame, this reviewers previous favorite of theirs. Frozen Tears is a near perfect album without a single weak track on it with a nice diversity , you have several fairly straight-up symphonic power metal numbers, such as Sea of Fate and Raging Starfire, an Italian Folk song type number, one of the best ballads they have ever done: Lost in Cold Dreams, but the real highlight of this album is track 4, Reign of Terror, one of the most bombastic, symphonic powerful songs they have ever recorded, it has everything but the kitchen sink: melody, catchy riff,sheer heaviness, symphonic bobasity, and a dash of black metal. This bands lyrics and subject matter have always been, in my opinion, cheesier than all the lasagna in Italy, but I listen to them for their musicianship and musical craftsmanship, both of which are stellar on this release, unlike the last two albums that I found to be lackluster and unmemorable. If you are already a fan you can pick this up without hesitation. If you are a curious metal head, I can tell you this will easily be one of the best releases of 2010, so check it out.

B0013FXWU6|5.0|When I first saw There Will Be Blood, I was disappointed. While I enjoyed the performance of Daniel Day-Lewis and I appreciated the gorgeous cinematography, the film did not do much for me, and it felt pretentious and overlong.<br /><br />What a difference a second viewing makes. The second time around, I found the pacing of the film to be patient instead of slow, and I was better able to see all the layers of Daniel Day-Lewis' performance: he is absolutely mesmerizing as the mysterious and deeply amoral Daniel Plainview. The lack of any backstory or context provided for him and his son, H.W., will no doubt frustrate some filmgoers, and this film is certainly not for everyone, but I love the ambiguity and find it rather thought-provoking.<br /><br />Every time I come back to this film, I find something new in it; the more I see it, the stranger and sadder it seems to get. Many critics have taken issue with third act, but I would compare this film's third act to the ending of Apocalypse Now; frustratingly messy for some filmgoers, but I loved it. There's an anarchy and chaos to this filmmaking that really does reflect the most negative implications of a libertarian approach to society that enables (if not encourages) people like Daniel Plainview: liberty, self-reliance, and competition can be good in certain instances, but this can lead to a certain cold-bloodedness that can be very problematic.<br /><br />This film really penetrates to the heart of the American tradition of rugged individualism, and seems to comment on the implications of living under a capitalistic economic system: with each new viewing, more layers seem to be revealedthe performances seem to get better and better, and the political commentary grows sharper and sharper. Daniel Day-Lewis has given many fine performances, but this is clearly his crowning achievement, and this film serves as further proof that Paul Thomas Anderson is pretty much the best filmmaker alive.

B001UV4XFG|3.0|\\"The Twilight Saga: New Moon\\" abruptly ended with Edward Cullen (Robert Pattinson) telling his girlfriend, Bella Swan (Kristen Stewart) that he will turn her into a vampire on the condition that they get married first. And so \\"The Twilight Saga: Eclipse,\\" the third film in a series serving as an extended metaphor for abstinence, begins with the two lovingly lying in a field of flowers, and you can sense the anticipation they both feel, especially Bella, who radiates with virginal longing. As bothersome as I found this twice before, this time around I found it oddly amusing, maybe because, after their painfully statuesque performances in \\"New Moon,\\" Stewart and Pattinson are once again allowed to emote. Stewart especially, who takes on a whole different energy when she's given the opportunity to crack a smile.    Alas, it's quickly hampered by a scene in which the metaphor turns literal; Bella wants to have sex with Edward while she's still human, but his chivalrous standards kick into high gear and he refuses her advances. He then lectures her on how, back in his day, he would have courted her, taken chaperoned walks with her, asked her father's permission for her hand in marriage, and so on and so forth. He then tells her that, while his soul is done for, hers is still worth preserving. What I find intriguing is that Stephenie Meyer wove such blatant themes into a fantasy, a genre created specifically as a way to escape reality. Even if sex before marriage is forbidden by Mormon doctrine, what's to stop her from writing about it? If I were her, I would have had Bella and Edward go at it like dogs in heat, all the while remembering that my personal values haven't been affected.    Complicating Bella's situation is the hot-blooded, mostly shirtless werewolf Jacob Black (Taylor Lautner), who professes his love for her as well as his hatred of Edward, the Cullen Clan, and vampires in general. Does Bella feel the same way about Jacob? She's not entirely sure. All she knows is that she needs both him and Edward to protect her, which means they will have to find some way to get along. It seems that, up in nearby Seattle, the evil vampire Victoria (Bryce Dallas Howard) has been busy recruiting an army of young vampires, or newbies, for purposes of attacking the Cullen Clan and getting revenge against Bella; aware of this, the Cullens join forces with their blood enemies, the werewolves, in the hopes of putting a stop to the newbies, who are apparently much more lethal than their older counterparts.    Despite the preachy subtexts, \\"Eclipse\\" is an improvement - albeit a tepid one - from the previous two \\"Twilight\\" films. I appreciated the greater emotional range displayed by Stewart and Pattinson, I liked looking at the none-too-convincing visual effects, and I found the action sequences more exciting, sparse though they may be. All the same, it still suffers from excessive length and unreasonable pacing, and just like before, they're linked to tedious conversations between the leads. I was especially fed up with Edward's repeated attempts to talk Bella out of becoming a vampire, and likewise, with her insistence on going through with it. The more I hear the Cullens describe the required sacrifices, the less I'm inclined to side with Bella; aging and death are frightening, but soulless immortality is unthinkable.    Lautner is still a chiseled hunk for the girls to swoon over, which may adequately distract them from the fact that he spends virtually all of his performance angrily clenching his jaw. When Jacob isn't romantically sulking, then he's furiously confronting Edward. Nowhere is this more apparent than in a tent high atop a snowy mountain, in which Bella, her teeth chattering from the cold, lets Jacob embrace her for his body heat: \\"Let's face it,\\" he tells Edward, \\"I am hotter than you.\\" As Bella sleeps, Jacob and Edward glower at each other, and they quietly but firmly discuss the fact that Bella still has to make a choice,and that, if she had been given enough time, she already could have made it. So I guess the question is simple, especially if you've been eating at Burger King: Is Bella on Team Jacob or Team Edward?    \\"The Twilight Saga: Eclipse\\" will almost certainly please the fans, just as they were pleased twice before. Non fans will have a rougher time of it, although I suspect it will be easier to win them over with this film than it was with the first two. As for myself, I recognize its progress as the third chapter of a series, but it's still too slow, too overwrought, and too didactic for me to recommend it. You've got to hand it to Stephenie Meyer - she really knows how to sermonize. I might have gotten something out of it had the topic been less divisive, however. Aren't there moral themes that we all more or less agree upon, such as treating everyone with respect or being charitable or something along those lines? If I'm going to be preached at, and if it has to be in the form of a vampire romance, at least make sure that the message is making good sense.
031604461X|1.0|I hate this book.    And not just hate.  Hate is not nearly a strong enough word.  I had a physical reaction to this book, and it wasn't a good one.  I loathe and detest this thing to a level not previously experienced by anything else I've ever read.    I'm fairly certain I've never said that about anything that I wasn't forced by a school system to read.  And even then it was few and far between and nowhere near this magnitude.  Almost everything I've ever read I can attribute some sort of merit.  Sadly, I can't say that here.  That being said, I wanted to like this book.  In fact, I wanted to love it, I wanted to cuddle up beside it at night and be blown away by its brilliance.  I wanted all those little nuggets of cryptic information I wondered about in the past books to be pulled together in some divine machination, I wanted sweeping romance, I wanted a deepening backstory and a broadening arc, I wanted characters to evolve past their situations and limitations.  I wanted the relationship between them to come together in a way that would shock me by its sheer simplicity and elegance, only to look back on the ones that came before and say, `you know, I should have seen that the whole time'.    What I wanted, in short, was a payoff.    Maybe that's a lot to ask.    But what I got in return for my devotion and all the inherent flaws that came before that I was willing to overlook for the sake of the ending, was this absolute hot mess of a story that took my beloved hero and heroine and threw them callously in the mud.  And worse is that it makes no sense whatsoever in the thematic context of the series.  It flagrantly goes against all the characterization and plot elements that were set out before it.  The last entry in a \\"saga\\", if we can really bring ourselves to label it that, is supposed to pay homage to what has come before, set you on your course and then pull the rug out in an unexpected, but completely fulfilling way.  The trick of a great finale is that you are supposed to see the path laid before you and then, even before you know what hits you, the story flips in a way that is better than you could have ever thought.      It's been done before.  So it's not impossible.  Evidently it just wasn't possible here.     So for a brief primer on the past, Eclipse left us with Bella agreeing to marry Edward in exchange for changing her himself in exchange for attempting to make love while still a human on their honeymoon.  In my mind, these three items are the primary plotting points for Breaking Dawn.  And on all accounts they're good ones.      1. The wedding  2. The honeymoon  3. The changing    I must note here that I am not a tremendous fan of Eclipse.  I think as far as the trilogy is concerned - BD is by far and away the weakest in the supposed \\"saga\\" - Eclipse has the most holes in its plot logic.  But at its heart, we see Bella coming to terms with the decision she's made, what she's giving up, and who she's chosen, once and for all, playing out thematically the valid questions of choice and consequence.        So here they are.      The top 10 reasons why Breaking Dawn kills this story and destroys it for all eternity.    Problem 1 - Bella Herself    One of the overreaching problems of BD is that there is no real development in Bella's character throughout.  Some might say she does become a wife - not a very good one in my opinion - and a mother - which was not her choice and was a plot device literally thrust upon her.  Eclipse tells us that choice - Bella's choice - is of vital importance to who we become, yet, choice is all but thrown out the window in BD in more than one situation and for more than one character.  But the beginning of BD finds her begrudging once again the Cullen lifestyle she doesn't want and still pining away for a lost Jacob.  Irritating!  She is not imprinted to Jacob.  She is not his soul mate.  She chooses a life and a particular life choice with Edward and up until and including her own wedding day, she is still questioning the decision.  BD turns Bella into an even more unlikeable, insipid and vapid girl - not a woman by any stretch of the imagination - than we saw her in Eclipse.  I liked Bella in Twilight.  I liked her in New Moon.  I questioned her in Eclipse, but understood why and that she had to be that way to figure out what she wants.  But by the time BD rolls along, she shouldn't still be thinking of dear old Jake.  Your husband is waiting, Bella, pull it together!  And further, it is glaringly clear that she still doesn't really want to marry him.  I know we get her supposed revelation to that effect somewhere around page 500.  500 pages later!  Where is the sweetness?  The poignancy?  The excitement of her pending marriage and life with the man she loves?  Poor Edward just can't catch a break!  In fact, Bella devolves in BD.  She never comes to a greater understanding of anything - her life, her husband, her family, her eternity.  She is the same Bella we first met in Twilight, now just with the accessories of a wedding ring and a baby.    Problem 2 - The Wedding    It is a wedding.  It is the wedding of our two lovers.  It should encompass more than a few pages of exposition and barely a page of `I do' dialogue.  I got to the end of the wedding wondering why in the world the darn book was so long.  If one of the major plot points lasted barely a chapter, what would the rest be like?  Not to mention, here's Jacob again, fueling the fire on Bella's continuing and ridiculous questioning of whether she made the right decision even after they've sealed the deal.  And Jacob, man, it's her freaking wedding.  I know Edward invited you and all, but show a little respect.  Don't pick a fight in the middle of the reception.  I guess overall I was just looking for a little more romance.  You'd think a wedding might tend to bring that out.  Or perhaps not.      Problem 3 - The Honeymoon, or more precisely, the Wedding Night    There are so many problems with this one, you'll just have to bear with me.    One of the major problems I have with this book is that it truly just doesn't make any sense.  I pretty much knew going into it that I wasn't going to get the fantastically monumental sex scene that I wanted.  And that in itself, I feel, is a problem.  They are adults - Bella is almost nineteen, people can vote and be shipped off to war younger than that and Edward by his own admission was already presumed a man in his time at seventeen.  They are married.  Married adults have sex.  Outside of the context of this extremely pivotal event in the lives of our beloved characters, not to mention the probably hundreds of pages and thousands of words of dialogue that have paid tribute to this one single event, we, the evidently unimportant reader, are not found to be mature enough to handle this subject matter.  And really, I'm offended by it.  BD is not a high school novel.  The characters, with the exception of Jacob, are no longer in high school, but really does he even go to school, and the fact that we are not given at least one real and satisfying look into the intimacy between these two characters astounds me.  But I get it.  Somewhere along the way, our fearless author was probably told something along the lines of this.  Nine years olds will read this book.  And we want them to because it means more money for us all.  But since they will, you can't write any of the good stuff because freaked out mothers and grandmothers and religious associations and grammar school libraries will drive a stake in us faster than you can say Dracula.  And because of it, the book suffers.  It's way too tame for the level of love - and lust - it's been building up to.    However, this by itself, it not the only problem in our much anticipated wedding night.  It may actually be the smallest of several.  For three books, Edward has been resisting his sexual temptations in a noble effort to a.) marry her first - CHECK; and b.) keep her from getting hurt.  On countless occasions his primary argument has been, I can't put my marble masculinity in your fragile femininity without serious harm befalling you.  Not to mention all the naked friction might release my inner demons and you might end up dead either by fracture up the middle or by sheer blood loss.   And you know what?  He was right!  Apparently down pillows help in the teeth ripping department.  Who knew?  And I for one didn't find the destroyed to the point of utter shambles bedroom and dried feather infested hair very romantic.  What is romantic about a night of passion that requires a clean up crew?  But I digress.  So our heroine wakes up from her night of wedded and bedded bliss bruised and battered from cheeks to toes.  So much so that our morning after which should be enjoyed basking in the glow of newly experienced sex is ugly and insulting and brutally depressing.  What the heck happened?  And what does this tell us?  It tells us that Edward is, in fact, the monster he thinks he is.  And what that tells us further is that maybe he was right about everything and Bella should have never married him in the first place.  Again, what the heck?  The key to the wedding night sex scene, as all us readers know and apparently the author doesn't, is that Edward is much more human than he thinks he is.  That he would never hurt her.  That Bella is right on this one and he isn't.  They should have had an evening of bliss.  She should have woken wrapped in down provided warmth in the arms of the man she loves.  He should be relaxed and open and ready to embrace this new chapter of their lives where what he thought was true may not actually be true, leading him to question all the other things he might be wrong about.  (Flashing lights: His Soul)  In short, they should have both come out of this UNSCATHED.  Again, I am offended that their first night together went to such a horribly bad place.  Further, I found it gallingly unacceptable toassume that Edward in his infinite eye to detail and to the safety and well-being of his wife, didn't ask his omniscient sister what was going to happen.  Embarrassing, yes.  Optional, no.   He would have asked Alice.  And if he had, she would have told him and if she told him `you're going to beat her senseless', newsflash, he wouldn't have done it.  And if he hadn't, the entire rest of the story couldn't have happened.      And that isn't even the most utterly preposterous of the many utterly preposterous plot devices of this piece of garbage.  We all know what happens.  Bella is not only battered but knocked up.  And what does that teach us, fair reader?  We aren't talking pre-marital sex here.  We are talking mostly consensual , loving, respect for one another, committed for the rest of eternity, married sex.  And she gets pregnant right of the gate.  Didn't they even discuss birth control?  They didn't.  And I'll tell you why.  They didn't need to.  Because - and here is Number 1 in the most utterly preposterous plot devices in this book - Edward shouldn't be able to do it.  And you know what I'm talking about.  It's never referenced specifically, which is again a nod to our immaturity as readers, but what is referenced on multiple occasions is the fact that Bella needs \\"human moments\\".  Translation: she has to go to the bathroom.  And Edward doesn't.  It's the same equipment, folks.  If it doesn't work one way, it shouldn't work the other.  And this isn't the only example.  Does he cry?  No.  Does he sweat?  No.  Does he require a shower to maintain his perfection?  No.  And yet we are to believe that he can ejaculate?  Stupid, stupid, stupid.  And again, without this baseless and ridiculous device, the rest of the story doesn't happen.    As for the rest of the honeymoon, it's largely forgettable.  Some evidence of better sex, but by that time the damage, both literally and figuratively, is done.  And, ironically, just at the time Bella decides she likes thismarriage-sex-human situation and wants to continue it on to Dartmouth for a few more years, and Edward comes out of his self-induced funk, a rather unexpected development pops up.  Or more correctly, pops out.      Problem 4 - The Pregnancy    While I've already outlined that the pregnancy itself shouldn't have even happened due to the gaping holes in the plot logic, when I discovered that Bella was, indeed, pregnant with Edward's child, I thought, maybe this could actually go places, maybe there's something interesting to be gotten from this, maybe this could be Edward's redemption - because, let's face it, Book 4, though told by Bella should really have been about their mutual evolution to a better place and Edward's ultimate redemption from the hell he's thinks he's confined to.  But I was wrong.  Upon learning this unbelievable knowledge - truly unbelievable - what is Edward's first thought?  Abort it.  Let me cut you open and rid you of my seed.  I understand the guilt.  To me, I pictured Edward when human was probably Catholic.  He's from Chicago.  Makes sense.  And he's got massive God and Guilt issues.  But the abortion thing seems way out of character.  He's always wanted a life, a real life, a real family.  He tells Bella more than once that she'll regret losing the opportunity to have children if he changes her.  He points out Esme and Rose as examples of women left to deal with a life without possibility for holding a little one in their arms.  He all but tells her that she's too young to understand that yet.  And that he does and he regrets it.  And then upon being given the opportunity, he completely freaks out.  And what does Bella, clear thinker that she's always been, do?  She calls Rosalie!  She doesn't try to reason with her husband.  She doesn't try to make him understand her desire to want it, to keep it, to love it.  They don't work as a team to get through this unexpected and actual bump in the road of marriage.  There are bumps, as any married person can tell you.  Thereby proving once again how she hasn't matured ounce one since the wishy-washy Bella of Eclipse and undermining both the foundation of their relationship and our faith in Edward as problem solver and husband extraordinaire.  What happens?  She cuts him out of the loop altogether and runs off to Rose.  Who by now, she should know is the most untrustworthy of all her new in laws and couldn't care less about her.    Problem 5 - The Return    I'll admit, this is where they lost me.  I'd given up by this time in trying to understand this story.  And had realized that all the epic romance and growing maturity I'd hoped for my beloved characters had been squelched, staked and set on a pyre of fire to die.  Nothing good could come of this.  And it didn't just get bad.  It got really bad.  And not just bad, but boring.  For one thing, we now turn to Jacob to become the voice of our story in his slanted and prejudiced perspective.  I'll admit, I never liked Jacob.  Three books, never liked him.  And interestingly, he is the only character I even remotely liked in BD.  Bella is selfish, immature, emotionally stunted, manipulative, secretive and boring.  Edward is weak, helpless, unconvincing, self-pitying, pathetic and unintelligent.  The fact that I feel such terrible things about both of them speaks of the banal and prosaic quality of this story.  This story destroys our hero.  Makes him not even likable.  Turns him into a fractured shell of the man we loved.  Further, the fact that the entire pregnancy and middle chunk of this book is told by Jacob is a poor, poor mistake.  And here's the reason.  We see Edward, broken, buried, on his knees begging Jacob not only to kill him when the time comes, but to impregnate his wife!  He's pimping out his wife!  I understand this is supposed to be a noble gesture, his love for Bella superseding his own jealousy and thereby giving her the normal child that he can't.  But come on!  This is ludicrous!  In whatworld are we supposed to appreciate this?  Let alone like it?  And we see Bella, and for some unbeknownst reason vampire pregnancies are really super speedy, with the gestation that's turning her into a human weeble-wobble who can't seem to get off the couch except to pee.  Oh right, it's because it's killing her.  Breaking her bones from the inside out.  Again, what a lovely picture.  A baby that's killing her.  No romance there.  And suddenly Jacob's original argument doesn't look quite as insane.  But fundamentally, the fact that we only hear from Jacob exacerbates the problem.  We don't know what's going on behind closed doors.  We don't know what Bella has said to Edward.  What Edward has said to Bella.  We only know what Jacob hears directly or thinks about what he hears directly.  This is a BIG mistake.  Maybe I'd feel some sympathy for either of them if I actually had conversations to mull over.  Since we don't, all we have is what we assume.  Bella is a big pain in the butt who's kicked them all to the wayside except for Rose who doesn't care if Bella lives or dies as long as she's got the baby.  And Edward is hapless and completely ineffectual to talk any amount of sense into his wife or to comfort her and guide her through a strenuous and difficult pregnancy.  Despite his best efforts, a solid marriage these two do not have.  I can't tell you how irritated I became with all those scenes of Alice sitting on the ground with her head in her hands and Bella on the couch in some kind of transcendental state cooing over the fetus busting open her ribs and Rose carrying her to the bathroom or to bed like a crazy nurse maid waiting to steal a newborn from its dead mother and Edward basically throwing up his hands in a big whatever.  Total and complete nonsense!  And I'm not even going to go into all the Bella blood drinking.  The one and ONLY semi sweet redeeming moment in the entire book came when Edward heard his little tykes thoughts from the womb.  What if we'd have an entire book of that?  Wouldn't that have been better than this gigantic pile of crap?    PROBLEM 6 - The Birth and Change    My main problem with this part is not so much the birth itself, which is disgusting and way more graphic than a sex scene would have been, but it really boils down to the nature of Bella's changing.  Why does Edward change Bella?  Because she going to die if he doesn't.  She is ripped apart, the baby eaten, yes eaten out of her by her own husband's vampire teeth, her spine is broken and she's left virtually in pieces and bloodletted to boot.  The fact that she isn't dead already is a miracle.  Yes, I know she's strong, strong enough to keep her heart beating.  Yes, I know she's sacrificing everything for her child, which is what good mothers do.  I got all that.  What I don't get is this.  Bella's changing goes against everything we've been taught about Edward's character.  He has to do it.  He has no choice but to do it.  It's an afterthought.  There are no consequences to his actions.  The story is much more compelling and gives their relationship much more substantial weight when there is a choice to be made.  The entire series we are told the Edward does not want to change Bella.  That he values her human life above everything else.  The fact that her changing is done in such a haphazard and distasteful way speaks volumes to the lack of credibility in this story.  We saw at the end of their honeymoon that Bella wanted to stay human, that she wanted to go to Dartmouth, that she might have even been questioning her decision in a way more profound than Team Edward vs Team Jacob.  And then she is given no choice in the matter.  Or more pointedly, she is given a choice.  Become a vampire or die.  According to Edward, both those things equal death.  We've seen no miraculous metamorphosis of his philosophy in the one month it's taken her to bear his child.  So what's the deal?  A weak plot.  That's the deal.  There should have been achoice made.  A conscious choice made by Edward to end his beloved's life against his better judgment, to condemn her to his existence and be able to live with, or perhaps endure is a better word, those consequences.  The fact that he does it simply because he has to is reckless and thoughtless.  It's a grade F cop out.       Problem 7 - The Imprint    Perhaps the single most horrendous plot twist in all of fiction.  Enough said.    Problem 8 - Bella the Vampire    Happily we go merrily onward with Bella the perfect vampire.  For many reasons, I never wanted to see that happen.  The greatest twist to this saga, in my opinion, would have been if an immortal eternity didn't turn out to be Bella's future.  If what she expected to happen, wasn't what happened.  Could you imagine the possibilities?  And in my mind, they aren't all bad.  I'm not talking about Team Jacob here.  I'm simply talking about, from the perspective of plot and characterization and the most engaging and fulfilling story, what if what we think is going to happen, doesn't happen?   Just something to chew over.  Although I will say, quite honestly, that this is not where I expected this story to go.  I really thought that at its depth, this was a story that would go the other direction.  Humanity would win out for Bella.  That it didn't?  Well, call me surprised.  In any event, it is what it is.  I'm not greatly offended that Bella adjusts so quickly and that there's really no thirst for human blood and that she seems 100% in control of her newly acquired lifestyle.  I know some people that are.  That fact is, by this point, I really just didn't care.  I didn't want Bella to be a vampire, therefore I don't care whether she's a good one.  What I do care about is this.  Once again, this road takes us to a place that flies against everything we've been taught before.  In three books and 1800+ pages, we have never, EVER, heard Edward mention one single solitary time how great it is to be a vampire.  We'venever heard that from ANY of them.  Edward hates being a vampire.  He didn't want to be one, doesn't want to be one, has frequently taken out his anger at being one on innocent victims and just as frequently tried to devise ways of putting himself out of his misery by ending his staying one.  Further, Rosalie, in perhaps the only smart piece of advice in all of Eclipse, tells Bella she's making a huge mistake by so arrogantly giving up her life.  Not that it matters by this point.  But now we are suddenly supposed to believe that everything is lollipops and roses in vampireland.  It's fantastic even.  I'm beautiful.  (Edward supposedly thought she already was).  I'm strong.  (Because everyone needs to be able to smash a boulder with their bare hands).  I'm not the least bit clumsy anymore.  I can hunt deer while wearing a cocktail dress.  I can tear down buildings while having sex with my husband.  I have a really disturbingly creepy daughter who's half human and half vampire and betrothed from birth to a wereworlf, who, I'm sorry, might have some therapy in her future.  And worst of all, Bella inwardly opines that it's almost like she was born for this.  That as a human, she was nothing special, not particularly smart (not true, if you remember in Twilight it was her intelligence that second sparked Edward's interest, we all know her scent was the first), not particularly pretty, not particularly worthy, not particularly anything.  So if all that was true, why in the hell would the mysterious, dashing, charming, articulate, witty, uber-intelligent Edward fall for you in the first place?  It is revolting to a fault.  Bella as a human was nothing.  And Edward was wrong - once again, this is becoming a bit of a habit - to have ever withheld from her such an inspiring life.  Was Edward right about anything?  Moreover, even as happy little vampires, their relationship is never explored, their marriage never deepens.  They never evolve past seventeen and eighteen.  We are told they have more sex.  We are told Bella loves her child.  I don't remember Edward specifically saying that, or being grateful for becoming a father, but I'm giving him the benefit of the doubt.  No mention of Dartmouth ever takes place again.  No mention of living on their own - outside a nearby cottage - is ever suggested.  They remain completely inert.  The fact is, this story has no heart.  It has no soul.  There's no romance.  There's no feeling of an epic journey.  All it is, is Bella becomes a vampire.  Because evidently she's better that way.  And more evidently, she knew that all along and Edward was stupid for not just changing her way back on prom night.  Although now they have a creepy child that will out age them both in just a few years.    Problem 9 - Unnecessary Developments    I see a couple of ways this could have been better.  Either simply end the story with Bella being happily vampired and save an entire forest of trees in the couple hundred pages of story we could have been spared, or perhaps delve, with even a grain of wisdom or insight, into married life for Mr. and Mrs. Cullen.   We didn't get either of those things.  Instead we got what amounted to a completely different story hinging entirely on misunderstandings, unnecessary characters introduced meant to what - I have a sneaking suspicion it involves large amounts of $$$ and additional books on uninteresting and tertiary characters - and the arrival once again of the Volturi.  I don't want an action novel.  If I wanted that, I would have read something else.  Eclipse had action.  BD should have a different mood, we shouldn't be rehashing this fight the Volturi thing again.  It's tiresome, derivative and more than anything else, just some sort of pointless action sequence to put in the movie.  It's like they can't be allowed any happiness.  Even in eternity, happiness is fleeting apparently, even if you're with your one true love who's given up her life for you.  There's always someone who wants to kill you.  Call me old fashioned.      Problem 10 - The Shield    Have a mentioned how much I hate this book?  Ok, so Bella isn't just the world's most well adjusted vampire.  She's also got this super power thing going on.  We are to believe that the gods of vampire destiny sent Bella to Forks to meet and fall in love with Edward - after a brief fling with Jacob - all because she is the vampire savior with this thing she pops out of her head like a cartoon balloon, in which she can expand it to include all her loved ones and keep them safe.  Did we just jump genres?  Bella the Super Vampire?  Does she need a cape and a sidekick?  Oh right, Edward's the sidekick, reduced in this pathetic story to nothing more than sperm donor.  Edward's talent, though it plagues him, is at least interesting.  Alice's is useful despite the mind numbing headaches.  Bella's is just trite and reaching for a now audacious level of absurdity.  Once again reiterating that she was nothing as a human, but that all the doors of the world have opened to her as a vampire.  Humanity, as it turns out, was Bella's greatest weakness after all, both inside and out.  Funny, for three books that was what Edward found most endearing.  Geez, wasn't he an idiot?  Then again, weren't we all?  And the greater question is this.  Why does Bella need a super power?  Why does one need to be invented for her?  I was led to believe Edward loved her exactly the way she was?  I was led to believe that being human was enough.  Evidently, it's not.  Evidently I've somehow found myself misdirected to the Sparkly Skinned Super Friends hour.     In short, I was left shaking my head to the last page wondering how in the world this opportunity to shine went so terribly wrong.  At its essence the culmination of this story should have been a man and a woman growing up, if not in age, then in maturity, making the choices together that would define them and the life they'd build together, overcoming all theobstacles set before them to love each other in a real and powerful way.  Like a roller coaster that jumps the tracks and plummets to the ground, this waste of time took me on a ride that I don't ever want to go on again.  For shame, Ms. Meyer, the characters deserve better than this.

1557280290|2.0|I was prepared to like/love this book, as so many reviewers I respect (including the novelist who wrote the foreword) call it a great novel. It is well written....but about characters I would not want to spend time with in life. The title character, an only child, is flat emotionally, as were his parents.  I read that the author views Stoner's life as a triumph solely because he did what he wanted to do (teach literature).  It didn't FEEL like a triumph. A depression hovers over Stoner and the novel. For most of his career he wasn't a good teacher; his long marriage was a disaster; his university career was dead-ended by a rival. He dies forced into an early retirement, tended by the neurotic wife from whom he has been estranged for decades. I want to find one character who holds my interest in any novel I read--even a villain, as long as (s)he's compelling. I didn't find one here.
B000TGJ7ZY|3.0|This review covers the transfer quality of the bluray disc, not the movie which is one of my favorites and certainly a 5 star film. The problem with the Bluray edition of BSD versus the Superbit release is simple: the transfer to 1080 BD is very uneven. By this I mean the contrast is all over the board; colors are brilliant in one scene and in the next washed out or dull; one moment you are admiring the clarity, the next it's fuzzy and out of focus. The viewing experience is remarkably inconsistant and at times can get a bit annoying to see these very vbisible transfer flaws. I have no problems with the sound of the Bluray release, which sounds very similar to the Superbit DVD DTS AC3 soundtrack.    The BD does come with some nice supplemental bonus features. I will keep this release for that reason. But if I plan to ever watch BSD on my Bluray player, it will be with the Superbit DVD, which when upscaled is leagues better in the video department.

B000HTMQW4|5.0|A long time friend of mine who is the best French chef I've ever known (including all but one French restaurant I've ever eaten at, and she is that chef's equal), recommends the 15th printing of this book from 1967 as the best version. Although she didn't go into details, she explained that subsequent editions change techniques and some recipes for the worse.<br /><br />I was able to find a copy on eBay with no problem, and I've seen it here at reasonable prices. We've owned ours and enjoyed meals cooked from it for many years now.<br /><br />HINTS: Try the French Pan Fried Steaks. You'll never want to prepare a steak any other way again.<br /><br />The Coquille St. Jacques (scallops in a creamy wine sauce) is outstanding, but one warning, quite a time sink in preparation.<br /><br />The Tomatos Provencale are very easy to make and are a great side for most fancy meals. It is permissible to go easy on the oregano depending on your taste.<br /><br />Mushroom Soup is another time sink, yet it will be the best soup you've ever tasted.<br /><br />Crepes: easy to make (just be sure you have a wide, shallow pan), and you can fill them with various things to make either side dishes or desserts.<br /><br />The book will get you to quick and successful souffles. The key is in reducing the heat properly as you put the souffle in the oven. Remember that and you'll never have one fall.<br /><br />Last tip, order a copper mixing bowl at the same time you order this book.

031604461X|2.0|WARNING: CONTAINS SPOILERS    It was a Friday afternoon in October of 2007, and there were only about twenty minutes until my very hectic school week would come to a close. Having completed all of our tasks for the day, myself and a few of the girls in my debate class formed a circle at the back of the room and began to discuss books. After agreeing on the fact that we all loved Scott Westerfield's Uglies series, my debate team member mentioned the Twilight Series. \\"What's Twilight?\\" I asked, imagining some lame Hobbit-esque fiction series. All of the girls looked to me in shock, their mouths open in wide little O's. \\"You haven't heard of Twilight?\\" one of them asked. The next few minutes were followed by the girls urging me to read this mysterious series,spouting out phrases like \\"awesome\\",\\"hot vampires\\", and \\"Edward Cullen\\" as my team member wrote down the order of the three novels on a piece of paper. She handed me the note as the class period came to a close, and I promised that I would begin reading them. The next day was a boring Saturday, and when my mom took a trip to our local bookstore, I tagged along. In the juvenile fiction section, I spotted many copies of Twilight. I was immediately intrigued by the pair of pale white hands offering up the forbidden apple, and I began reading as soon as I got home. I read the entire book in a single six hour sitting, and there was just something that I loved about it. Like Bella, I was seventeen years old, plain, and in a setting with a lot of new people. The fact that her love for Edward was so pure, yet so dangerous at the same time, fully blew my mind. I could not wait for more. Within the next month, I plowed my way through the three existing books of The Twilight Saga. There were only a handful of people at my school who had read them, so I really didn't have anyone to share my enthusiasm for this series with. All I could do was wait in terrible anticipation  for the final book to come out the next August. I purchased Breaking Dawn on the day that it hit the shelves, read it in a little less than eight hours...and immediately wished that I could have those eight hours of my life back. This book ruined any affection that I had for the Twilight Saga, and here is why:    We all know that Stephenie Meyer has some pretty conservative views on family, marriage, and sexuality, and I do not begrudge her for the traditional pearls of wisdom that she tries to instill in her readers.In fact, her conservatism is one of the things that I came to love about the series. Though Edward and Bella felt an intense and passionate physical attraction to one another, they were willing to wait until they officially belonged to one another before they had sex. I knew that the marriage and consumation of their relationship would come in the fourth book, and I could not wait for their happy ending. However, Stephenie Meyer's depiction of Bella and Edward's wedding, \\"first time\\", and the events that followed were very awkward and, dare I say it, grotesque. To me, it almost seemed as if Bella's wedding was happening entirely against her will. Alice Cullen showed up at Bella and Charlie's house on the day of the wedding, took her to the Cullen's home, and immediately forced her into a chair where she began applying her makeup and doing her hair. Instead of thinking about taking an important step in her life, Bella could only focus on how uncomfortable Alice was making her feel. She was then put into her dress and whisked down the stairs to be married. As she and Edward danced, she was still mourning the absence of her friend Jacob. After the reception, Alice forced luggage on Bella that she herself had packed, and then she and Edward headed off to their honeymoon on an uncharted island. Instead of being happy about their first time together, Edward boldly stripped in the ocean while Bella ran to the bathroom for sanctuary. After finally getting up the nerve, she took of her clothes and got into the waterwith her new husband. Now I can't speak for the rest of the readers, but after sitting through three novels that described Bella and Edward's passion in great detail, I expected some kind of sex scene. I don't mean something intensely graphic, but the kind of thing you would see in a PG-13 flick. Instead...we get nada. After stepping into the water with her man, Bella wakes up in a room to find herself covered in feathers and her new hubby lying beside her with a tortured look on her face. She discovers that she is covered head to toe in bruises, and Edward vows to not touch her again as long as she is human. Bella spends the next several days trying to seduce Edward before he finally caves. After her second experience, she decides that she would like to take Edward's advice and stay human for a little longer, go to college, and enjoy being married. However, her plans are thwarted when she discovers that (after a couple of weeks of vivid dreams, an insatiable craving for eggs, and some morning sickness) she is pregnant. She and Edward cut their honeymoon short and head back to Forks to \\"take care\\" of the situation. Though Edward and Carlisle want to get the baby out of Bella for her own safety, she is in love with and wants to give birth to it. After an accelerated pregnancy in which she drinks blood for her health and tries to make peace with Jacob, Bella is killed by the birth of her child and has to undergo emergency \\"vampirization\\" (Jacob's term, not mine). Jacob predictably imprints on the child, and after a feared battle with the Volturi amounts to nothing, all parties live happily ever after.    ...WWWWhhhaaatt?? In my opinion, this book was just one big mess. While I understand Meyer's need to promote traditional family values to her readers, there is no such thing as \\"normal\\" when supernatural creatures are involved. The whole story of Edward and Bella having a child was a little creepy, and hearing Bella describe the urge to drink from her father was a bit unnerving. Also, Jacob was my favorite person of the entire series, but Meyer reduced this very beloved boy into a pedophile in Breaking Dawn by having him imprint on a child. Call me immature if you would like, but that's what it is called when a seventeen/eighteen-year-old male falls for a newborn child with the intent to be romanctically involved with her some day: pedophilia. To make it worse, Meyer tells us that this creature called Renesmee will never mature physically past childhood. Um ,yeah, let's not take that mental picture into account. After reading this book, it made me wonder what Meyer's own marriage has been like. Was her own wedding full of uncomfortability as her future sister-in-law forced her to be her own personal Barbie doll for several hours? Was the wedding night full of anxiety to the point of physical illness, and the morning after plagued by her husband's self-hate? All in all, what was a very romantic series turned into every woman's worst  nightmare with Breaking Dawn. Because you do not get any closure with Eclipse, you must read this book to find out what happens with the series. But if I could spare you, I would recommend not wasting your time on this terribly grotesque waste of 800 pages.
B0018B1O7I|3.0|The Doors still makes various lists as one of the most important albums of the rock era, and certainly as one of the best debut albums of the era.  The album itself has been reviewed extensively, as have the various CD reissues; therefore, I will limit this review to the download version of it.  Since I own the vinyl release of The Doors and wanted to have it available for my iPod without all the crackles and sputters of converting the LP to digital format and didn't feel the need to own the physical CD, I opted for buying Amazon.com's MP3 download.  Each of the tracks clearly states \\"LP Version\\" in the listing for the download; however, Amazon has inexplicably included only the ineptly truncated single version of \\"Light My Fire.\\"  I feel that this is a complete misrepresentation of the album.  Afterall, this is perhaps the best-known song on The Doors.  Also, note that unlike the remixed CD that Amazon includes in the same listing as their MP3 version, here you won't find the \\"missing\\" lyrics of \\"Break on Through\\" and \\"The End.\\"  It is almost as though they have taken the original versions of the songs -- save the single version of \\"Light My Fire\\" -- and constructed a semi-remixed MP3 album.  The MP3 album's sound quality, though, generally is pretty good, and the songs do seem to have a punchier sound, certainly than on the original vinyl release.  Just be warned, the MP3 \\"album\\" DOES NOT include all the material from the original album -- the missing 4 minutes of \\"Light My Fire,\\" is perhaps the best part of the song, especially Ray Manzarek's organ solo and his comping behind Robbie Krieger's guitar solo.  I guess that I should have spent the extra dollar and purchased The Doors on iTunes.  Be forewarned and don't make the same mistake I made...  By the way, be aware that most of the reviews of this album that are included under the heading of MP3 downloads are actually of the CD release.  I believe that this may be the only review that specifies the deficiencies in the MP3 version.in the MP3 version.
