0446691437|5.0|I recommend this book to anyone out there struggling to bring some meaning into the world and satisfaction into his or her life.  This guy writes from a writer's perspective, but he's talking about anyone - any artist or any one who has a desire to create.<br /><br />  Here is an excerpt which shows how he ties the artist's life to the real world:<br /><br />  \\"In my younger days dodging the draft, I somehow wound up in the Marine Corps. . . Marines love to be miserable.  Marines derive a perverse satisfaction in having colder chow, crappier equipment and higher casualty rates than any outfit of dogfaces, swab jockeys, or flyboys, all of whom they despise. Why? Because these candy-asses don't know how to be miserable.<br /><br />  The artist committing himself to his calling has volunteered for hell, whether he knows it or not.  He will be dining for the duration on a diet of isolation, rejection, self-doubt, despair, ridicule, contempt and humiliation.<br /><br />  The artist must be like that Marine.  He has to know how to be miserable.  He has to love being miserable.  He has to take pride in being more miserable than any soldier or swabbie or jet jocky.  Because this is war, baby.  And war is hell.\\"<br /><br />  I got a huge laugh out of that entire section, because after all my years of writing, I know how much hell it really is, rejection after rejection.  It's comforting to know I'm not alone.  Read The War of Art by Steven Pressfield.  It's a hoot and a half,  with a reverence towards art and a deep respect towards those of us still struggling to produce it.

030726999X|5.0|If you're the type of Stieg Larsson fan who finished the first two books of the trilogy, and couldn't wait to get their hands on the third, then you'll likely find this a worthwhile excursion. If you ended \\"The Girl Who Played With Fire\\" with serious doubts about whether you wanted to continue, then this won't assuage your doubts. And it should go without saying that this is NOT the way you want to be introduced to the series.<br /><br />The narrative takes up right where the second book left off, so that helps it get off to a good start.<br /><br />Like the second book, there's a violent shocker in the relative early going.<br /><br />But while Larsson has concocted a wrongdoing-in-high-places scenario that might constitute earthshakingly scandalous behavior by Swedish standards, it won't seem extremely riveting to those who are used to American-based conspiracy thrillers (think \\"24\\" or any number of paranoia-based movies).<br /><br />The title is a bit misleading. Lisbeth Salander isn't causing a huge amount of trouble in this installment, she's mainly reacting to events in her typically inventive fashion. In fact, compared to some of the grief she caused in \\"The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo,\\" her goings-on are almost routine.<br /><br />Even a dialed-down Salander is the best part of the book, but there isn't nearly enough of her. While there's nothing particularly wrong with Kalle \\"F\\" Blomkvist, Erika Berger or the various law enforcement types, the book is merely entertaining when the narrative focuses on them, while it becomes riveting when Salander truly springs into action. The story is helped along by one or two returning villains whom you end up seriously rooting against (although the newer ones at the center of the conspiracy seem a bit bloodless)<br /><br />Meanwhile, there are some Swedish newsroom scenes and speeches about journalistic cutbacks that will ring eloquently familiar to those who have lamented the decline of U.S. print journalism. And there's a bit of legal drama that would undoubtedly make for some great movie scenes.<br /><br />I think it's best to consider this as Larsson intended it -- as the third section of one very long book. If you look at it in that fashion, and as a way of bringing a bit of closure to the story, and as giving yourself one last chance to hang out in this milieu, then you'll probably feel better about the experience.<br /><br />To use an analogy to pop culture phenomenon from a previous era, this ain't no \\"Return of the King.\\" However, it is a pleasureable way to pass the time, and at less than the cost of an average movie ticket, the hardcover will provide far more hours of enjoyment.<br /><br />I'm rating it five stars, because to say that I merely \\"liked\\" the book wouldn't do it justice. It's more like a Netflix four-star \\"really liked it.\\"<br /><br />It makes one wonder what exactly is contained in the partly-completed fourth installment that Larsson's surviving girlfriend supposedly possesses. At this point, I'm not sure I would drop everything and buy an advance copy of the fourth book. I'll wait for some other intrepid reviewer to tell me if the fourth installment is the one that finally fulfills the promise of this amazing character.ake for some great movie scenes. 0143115723|5.0|As a simple story about an underdog national rugby team beating all odds to win a championship, this would be a very good story.  What makes this story great, is that team has been chosen (by newly elected South African president Nelson Mandela) as a way to unite a South Africa torn by divisions caused by decades of government enforced segregation of blacks and pave the way for reconciliation between bitter enemies. Can the Springboks, a symbol of the old segregated government, truly make their motto \\"One Team, One Country\\" come true?       If you have watched \\"Invictus\\" be assured that this book has much more of the background to the people and events portrayed by the movie.  The added detail gives one a sharper understanding of many of the principle characters in the movie and the true scope of Mandela's brilliance.      Highly recommended!
